DOC.HEAD: Major Events in de Klerk's Administration
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Major events since F.W. de Klerk was inaugurated as president on Sept. 20. Sept. 20 _ De Klerk takes the oath of office at the Union Buildings in Pretoria, pledges to seek a South Africa ``free of domination and oppression.'' Oct. 2 _ Officials of the national government negotiate for the first time with activists on possible solutions to a three-year rent boycott in Soweto, the country's largest black township. Oct. 11 _ De Klerk confers for three hours with Anglican Archbishop Desmond Tutu and two other anti-apartheid church leaders. Oct. 15 _ On de Klerk's orders, the government unconditionally frees eight prominent long-term political prisoners, including Walter Sisulu, a senior leader of the outlawed African National Congress. Oct. 29 _ More than 70,000 cheering, chanting blacks attend a welcome home rally for Sisulu and his colleagues, the largest opposition meeting ever in South Africa, after de Klerk decides to allow it. Oct. 30 _ The president tells his Cabinet that all departmental budgets, including the military, will be cut. Nov. 9 _ De Klerk meets leaders of two white extremist groups, tells them right-wing violence won't be tolerated. Nov. 16 _ De Klerk declares that all remaining whites-only beaches will be opened to blacks and says the Separate Amenities Act, which allows segregation of lcoal facilities, will be scrapped ``as soon as possible.'' Nov. 28 _ De Klerk announces the scrapping of the National Management System, a controversial bureaucratic network which enabled police and army commanders to exercize control over black townships. Dec. 1 _ De Klerk travels to a summit meeting with President Houphouet-Boigny of the Ivory Coast. Dec. 7 _ De Klerk cuts mandatory military service for white men from two years to one and says some military bases and units will be eliminated. Dec. 13 _ De Klerk confers with jailed African National Congress leader Nelson Mandela at the presidential office in Cape Town. Dec. 15 _ De Klerk travels to a summit meeting with President Joaquim Chissano of Mozambique, whose leftist government in the past has accused South Africa of supporting a rebel insurgency.
